newsitem.title: USA: Mortgage rates fall below 8 percent.
newsitem.headline: Mortgage rates fall below 8 percent.

text.p: Mortgage rates this week fell below 8 percent for the first time since the end of March, as news of an agreement to balance the federal budget eased fears of rising interest rates, Freddie Mac said Thursday.

Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.94 percent, falling for the third week in a row, from 8.01 percent last week. The last time they dipped below 8 percent was in the week ended March 28 when they stood at 7.97 percent, it said.

Fifteen-year fixed rate mortgages also fell for the third week in a row to 7.47 percent from 7.53 percent the prior week. One-year adjustable mortgages inched down a fourth consecutive week to 5.82 percent from 5.84 percent.
A year ago, the 30-year rate averaged 8.24 percent, the 15-year 7.75 percent and the adjustable loan 5.80 percent.
"The markets reacted this week to the news of a balanced budget agreement between the White House and Congress," said Robert Van Order, Freddie Mac chief economist.
"The prospect of less government borrowing in the future takes pressure off interest rates, which accounts for the decline we see in these figures this week," Van Order added.
But many analysts expect another hike in interest rates when Federal Reserve policy-makers meet May 20.
Lenders charged an average of 1.6 percent in fees and points on both 30- and 15-year loans, down from 1.7 percent last week. Adjustable loan charges were unchanged at 1.4 percent.
Freddie Mac is a corporation chartered by Congress that buys mortgages from lenders and packages them into securities for investors.
Separately, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said the volume of U.S. mortgage applications rose 1.8 percent in the week ended May 2.
The volume of applications to refinance mortgages rose 6.1 percent in the latest survey week, while applications to purchase mortgages rose 0.9 percent.
